CHAPTER 147
Planning Commission
147.01   Establishment; members.
147.02   As Platting Commission.
147.03   Meetings.
147.04   Powers and duties.
147.05   Certification of zoning plan.
147.06   Basis for zoning Village.
147.07   Council may amend districting plan.
147.08   Administration of districting plan.
147.09   Public hearing.
147.10   Conflict.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Plat approval required - see Ohio R.C. 711.09
   147.01  ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERS.
   There is hereby established a Planning Commission to consist of five
members, the Mayor, one member of Council to be selected by Council for the
remainder of his term as a member of Council, and three citizens of the Village
to be appointed by the Mayor, one for the term of two years from date of
appointment, one for the term of four years from the date of appointment and
one for term of six years from date of appointment all to serve without
compensation. (Ord. 396. Passed 7-15-35.)
   147.02  AS PLATTING COMMISSION.
   The Planning Commission shall be the Platting Commission of the Village, and
have all the powers and duties provided by law for Platting Commissions.
(Ord. 396. Passed 7-15-35.)
   147.03  MEETINGS.
   Meetings of the Planning Commission shall be at the call of the Chairman.
(Res. 1733. Passed 1-26-76.)
   147.04  POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (a)    The Planning Commission shall have the authority to control the
height, design and location of buildings within the Village.
   (b)    The Planning Commission shall have the power to appoint or employ
such engineers and other professional service, and such clerks, draughtsmen and
subordinates as it shall deem necessary for the performance of its functions;
the expenditures for such service and employments to be within the amounts
appropriated for such persons by Council.
   (c)    The Planning Commission shall be empowered to frame and adopt a plan
or plans for dividing the Municipality or any portion thereof into zones or
districts, representing the recommendations of the Planning Commission, in the
interest of the public health, safety, convenience, comfort, prosperity or
general welfare, for the limitations or regulation of the height, the bulk and
location and uses of buildings and other structures and of premises in such
zones or districts, including percentage of lot occupancy, set back building
lines and area and dimensions of yards.
   (d)    It shall be the duty of the Planning Commission to make plans and
maps of the whole or any portion of the Village, and of any land outside the
Municipality which in the opinion of the Commission bears relation to the
planning of the Municipality, and to make changes in such plans or maps when it
deems same advisable. Such plans or maps shall show the Commission’s
recommendations for new streets, alleys, ways, bridges, parks, playgrounds, or
any other public grounds or improvements; and the removal, relocation, widening
or extension of such public works then existing. The Commission shall have the
power to control, preserve and care for historical land marks. Whenever the
Planning Commission shall have made a plan of the Municipality, or any portion
thereof, no public building, street, boulevard, park, parkway, playground or
public ground or part thereof shall be constructed in the Village or any
portion of such Village until and unless the location thereof shall be approved
by the Planning Commission. In case of disapproval the Planning Commission
shall communicate its reasons for disapproval of Council, and Council, by a
vote of not less than two-thirds of its members, shall have the power to
overrule such disapproval.
(Ord. 396. Passed 7-15-35.)
   147.05  CERTIFICATION OF ZONING PLAN.
   (a)    Whenever the Planning Commission certifies to Council any plan for
the districting or zoning of the Village according to the uses of buildings and
other structures and of premises, then Council, in the interest of the
promotion of the public health, safety, convenience, comfort, prosperity or
general welfare, may regulate and restrict the location of buildings and other
structures and premises to be used for trade, industry, residence or other
specified uses, and divide the Municipality into districts of such number,
shape and area as may be deemed best suited to carry out the purposes of this
chapter. For each of such districts, regulations may be imposed designating the
kinds or classes of trades, industries, residences or other purposes for which
buildings or other structures or premises may be permitted to be erected,
altered or used subject to special regulations.
   (b)    Whenever the Planning Commission certifies to Council any such plan
for the districting or zoning of the Village according to the height of
buildings and other structures, then Council in the interest of the promotion
of the public health, safety, convenience, comfort, prosperity or general
welfare, may regulate and limit the height of buildings and other structures
thereafter erected or altered, and for such purpose divide the Village into
districts of such number, shape and area as may be deemed best suited to carry
out the purposes of this chapter.
   (c)    Whenever the Planning Commission certifies to Council any such plan
for the districting or zoning of the Municipality according to the bulk and
location of buildings and other structures, including percentage of lot
occupancy, set back building lines, and area of yards and other open spaces,
then Council may, in the interest of the promotion of the public health,
safety, convenience, comfort, prosperity or general welfare, regulate the bulk
and location of buildings and other structures thereafter erected or altered,
the percentage of lot occupancy, set back building lines and the area of yards,
and other open spaces, and for such purposes may divide the Village into
districts of such number, shape and area as may be deemed best suited to carry
out the purposes of this chapter.
(Ord. 396. Passed 7-15-35.)
   147.06  BASIS FOR ZONING VILLAGE.
   The districting or zoning of the Village or part thereof may be based upon
any combination of two or more of the purposes described in this chapter. In
the determination and establishment of districts or zones buildings and other
structures may be classified on the basis of the nature or character of trade,
industry, profession or other activity conducted or to be conducted therein,
the number of persons, or families to reside in or use them, the public, quasi-
public or private nature of the use thereof, or upon any other basis relevant
to the promotion of the public safety, health, morals, convenience, prosperity
or welfare.
(Ord. 396. Passed 7-15-35.)
   147.07  COUNCIL MAY AMEND DISTRICTING PLAN.
   Council may, from time to time, amend or change the number, shape, area or
regulations within any district; but no such amendment or change shall become
effective, unless the ordinance proposing the same shall first be submitted to
the Planning Commission for approval, disapproval or suggestions, and the
Planning Commission shall have been allowed a reasonable time, not less than
thirty days for consideration and report.
(Ord. 396. Passed 7-15-35.)
   147.08  ADMINISTRATION OF DISTRICTING PLAN.
   The Planning Commission shall be authorized to administer the details of the
application, of the rules and regulations to be set forth in the districting
ordinance and regulations together with the power to hear and determine appeals
from refusal of building permits by the proper officers, and to administer the
regulations as therein specified.
(Ord. 396. Passed 7-15-35.)
   147.09  PUBLIC HEARING.
   Before any ordinance, measure or regulation authorized by this chapter may
be passed, Council shall hold a public hearing thereon and shall give thirty
days notice, and the text or copy of the text of such ordinances, measure or
regulation, together with the maps or plans or copies thereof forming part of
or referred to in such ordinance, measure or regulation, and the maps, plans
and reports submitted by the Planning Commission shall be on file for public
examination, in the office of the Clerk.
(Ord. 396. Passed 7-15-35.)
   147.10  CONFLICT.
   No ordinance, measure or regulation which violates, differs from or departs
from the plan or report submitted by the Planning Commission, shall take effect
unless passed or approved by not less than three-fourths of the full membership
of Council.
(Ord. 396. Passed 7-15-35.)

CHAPTER 151

Village of Ottawa shall be discontinued.  In order to promote an orderly
transition of authority and duties, all members regularly elected or appointed
to the Utilities Board shall serve until the term for which they were elected
or appointed has expired or until January 1, 2008, whichever occurs sooner.
   The duties, authority and responsibilities of the Utilities Board shall be
assumed and exercised  by the Village of Ottawa Council under the direction of
the Utilities Director. 
(Ord. 05-29.  Passed 12-12-05.)

CHAPTER 155
Treasury Investments
155.01   Interest to be paid into various funds.
CROSS REFERENCES

   155.01  INTEREST TO BE PAID INTO VARIOUS FUNDS.
   Interest income on treasury investments shall be paid into the following
Village funds: the General Fund, the Income Tax Fund, and the various utilities
revenue funds as determined by a committee comprised of the Mayor, the
Municipal Director and the Clerk-Treasurer of the Village of Ottawa and
approved by Council.  The one exception is in cases where the investment is
made with the proceeds from the sale of bonds or notes in which case such
interest shall be paid into the proper debt retirement fund.  Interest paid
into the Street CMR Fund and the State Highway Fund shall be based upon current
state requirements.
(Ord. 01-02.  Passed 1-22-01.)
CHAPTER 157
Employment Provisions
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Pursuant to Ordinance 95-22, passed August 15, 1995, the City
has adopted a Personnel Policies and Procedures Manual which repeals all

CROSS REFERENCES
   Welfare - see Ohio Const., Art. II, Sec. 34
   Workers’ compensation  - see Ohio Const., Art. II, Sec. 35; Ohio R.C. Ch.
4123
   Wages and hours on public works - see Ohio Const., Art. II, Sec. 37; Ohio
R.C. Ch. 4115
   Public Employees Retirement System - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 145
   Expenses for attendance at conference or convention - see Ohio R.C. 733.79

   Vacation credit - see Ohio R.C. 9.44

   157.01  BONDS OF OFFICIALS AND EMPLOYEES.
   (a)   Before entering upon the discharge of his duties, the following
officials and employees shall execute a bond approved according to law in the
amount set forth opposite his or her respective office or position:
 
Clerk-Treasurer         $50,000 (Surety Bond)
Income Tax Commissioner $25,000 (Blanket Bond)
   (b)   All employees in the Clerk-Treasurer and Income Tax Offices shall be
bonded in the sum of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000) which shall be a
blanket bond, unless otherwise established or fixed elsewhere in the Codified
Ordinances.
   (c)   All other officials and employees of the Village and all members of
Village Boards shall be bonded in the sum of two thousand five hundred dollars
($2,500), which shall be a blanket bond, unless otherwise established or fixed
elsewhere in the Codified Ordinances.
(Ord. 1089.  Passed 11-23-81; Ord. 01-01.  Passed 1-2-01.)
   157.02  PAYROLL PERIOD.
   Salaries of all officials and employees, unless Council directs otherwise,
shall be paid monthly, biweekly or weekly as determined by the Clerk-
Treasurer.  Any amounts due an employee shall be paid as soon as practicable
after the termination of employment has occurred. 
(Ord. 1089.  Passed 11-23-81.)
   157.03  VACATIONS.
   (a)   Each full-time employee, including full-time hourly-rate employees,
after service of one year with the Village, shall have earned and will be due
upon the attainment of the first year of employment, and annually thereafter,
eighty hours (two weeks) of vacation leave with full pay.  One year of service
shall be computed on the basis of twenty-six biweekly pay periods.
   (b)   A full-time employee with eight or more years of service with the
Village shall have earned and is entitled to one hundred twenty hours (three
weeks) of vacation leave with full pay.
   (c)   A full-time employee with fifteen or more years of service with the
Village shall have earned and is entitled to one hundred sixty hours (four
weeks) of vacation leave with full pay.
   (d)   A full-time employee with twenty-five years of service with the
Village shall have earned and is entitled to two hundred hours (five weeks) of
vacation leave with full pay.
   (e)   Such vacation leave shall accrue to the employee at the rate of three
and one-tenth hours each biweekly period for those entitled to eighty hours per
year; four and six-tenth hours each biweekly period for those entitled to one
hundred twenty hours per year; and six and two-tenths hours each biweekly
period of those entitled to one hundred sixty hours per year; and seven and
seven-tenths hours each biweekly period for those entitled to two hundred hours
per year. 
(Ord. 1089.  Passed 11-23-81.)
   (f)   All employees' vacation schedules shall be submitted to and approved
by their Division Head and Department Head.  The Department Heads shall submit
their vacation schedules to the Municipal Director for approval prior to taking
vacation.  The Municipal Director shall submit a vacation schedule to the Mayor
prior to taking vacation. The approved application for vacation form shall be
processed through the payroll system.
   (g)   Available vacation for an employment year shall be used prior to the
employment anniversary of the following year.  Vacation not used as set forth
herein shall be forfeited by the employee upon the anniversary of his/her
employment each year, unless prior written approval is received from the
Division Head, Department Head and Mayor to carryover hours.  Such written
permission shall be processed through the payroll system.  In no case shall an
employee be allowed to carry over more than one-quarter (1/4) of his/her annual
vacation or a maximum of fifty (50) hours, whichever is less.
(Ord. 04-31.  Passed 12-20-04.)
   (h)   Employees shall forfeit their right to take or to be paid for upon
termination, any vacation leave to their credit where such is in excess of the
accrual of two years.  Such excess leave shall be eliminated from the
employees’ leave balance.
(Ord. 1089.  Passed 11-23-81.)
   157.04  SICK LEAVE.
   (a)   Each employee shall be entitled for each completed eighty hours of
service, to sick leave of four and six-tenths hours with pay, which sick leave
shall be accumulated without limit.  Employees may use sick leave upon the
written permission of the department head for absence due to personal illness
or injury and for illness, injury or death in the employee’s immediate family. 
The written permission form shall be filed in the employee’s personal file in
the Clerk’s Office.  Immediate family for sick leave purposes shall be defined
as husband, wife, son, daughter and other persons at the discretion of the
Mayor.
(Ord. 1113.  Passed 4-25-83.)
   (b)   Any employee who is absent for more than two consecutive work days
shall present to the department head a doctor’s statement indicating the nature
of his illness or injury and the projected date of his return to work, together
with any conditions imposed by the doctor for his return to work.  The doctor’s
certificate shall be presented to the department head no later than the sixth
consecutive work day after the commencement of the employee’s absence or on the
third day of the employee’s absence or upon the return of the employee to work,
whichever is sooner.  This rule may be temporarily waived by the Mayor in
exceptional circumstances where the employee or a member of his family is
unable to provide the certificate for reasons beyond his control.  (Ord. 1141. 
Passed 12-17-84.)
   157.05  TERMINATION, RETIREMENT OR DEATH.
   (a)   Upon separation from service an employee shall be entitled to
compensation at his current rate of pay for all lawfully accrued and unused
vacation leave to his credit at the time of separation up to two years.
   (b)   In case of death of an employee such unused vacation leave shall be
paid in accordance with Ohio R.C. 2113.04 or to his estate.
(Ord. 1089.  Passed 11-23-81.)
   (c)   Upon retirement, an employee shall receive payment of accrued but
unused sick leave for active service with the Village if the employee has at
least eight years of service as a public employee.  Such payment shall be made
only once to any employee.  The amount of the payment shall be one-fourth of
the employee’s accrued but unused sick leave, up to a maximum payment of:
 
Length of Service Maximum Hours
8-24 years        240
25-29 years       320
30+ years         400
Payment under this policy shall eliminate all sick leave credit accrued by the
employee at the time of payment. 
   (d)   Payment of accrued but unused sick leave will be made to the estate of
a deceased employee.  The amount of the payment shall be one fourth of the
employee’s accrued but unused sick leave up to a maximum payment as established
in subsection (c) hereof.  Such payment shall be made in compliance with Ohio
R.C. 2113.04.
(Ord. 98-11.  Passed 5-11-98.)
   157.06  INSURANCE.
   Hospital and medical insurance as well as dental, vision and life insurance
shall be carried for full-time employees by the Village.  Family hospital and
medical insurance as well as dental, vision and life insurance shall be
available at an annual cost to the employee of 2.5% of the additional premium
which equates to the following annual cost:
      Spousal Coverage - $183.24
      Child/Children - $123.41
      Spouse & Child/Children - $303.53
   Elected officials are not eligible for insurance coverage through the
Village of Ottawa.
(Ord. 16-19.  Passed 12-19-16.)
   157.07  HOLIDAYS.
   (a)   Employees shall be entitled to the following holidays at regular pay:
 
New Year’s Day       January 1st
Martin Luther King Day Third Monday in January
Good Friday afternoon  One-half day
Decoration Day         Last Monday in May
Independence Day       July 4th
Labor Day              First Monday in September
Thanksgiving Day       Fourth Thursday in November
President’s Day      Fourth Friday in November
                       (moved from the Third Monday in February)
Christmas Day          December 25th
Columbus Day           Last working day prior to the observed Christmas holiday
                       (moved from Second Monday in October)
Veteran’s Day     Last working day following the observed Christmas Day
                       holiday (moved from November 11th)
   (b)   For employees working a Monday through Friday, 40-hour workweek, in
the event that any of the holidays mentioned above should fall on Saturday, the
Friday immediately preceding shall be observed as the holiday.  In the event
that any of the holidays fall on Sunday, the Monday immediately succeeding
shall be observed as the holiday.
   (c)   For employees who do not work a regular Monday through Friday
schedule, in the event that any of the holidays mentioned above should fall on
a day when the employee is not scheduled to work, the day the holiday is
observed shall be determined by the department head. 
   (d)   In the event any Village employee is required to work on any of the
above mentioned holidays, overtime per Section
157.08 shall apply.
   (e)   Employees who are classified as “part-time” shall be paid at the rate
of one and one-half times their regular rate when required to work on any of
the holidays set forth in this Section
157.07.
   (f)   Holidays specified herein shall constitute an 8-hour day and shall not
be charged to an employee’s leave. 
(Ord. 05-31.  Passed 12-19-05.)
   157.08  OVERTIME/COMPENSATORY TIME/FLEX-TIME.
   (a)   Employees shall be paid at the rate of one and one-half times the
hourly rate for all hours over forty hours actually worked in any one week.  A
week shall start at 12:00 a.m. on Sunday and end at 11:59 p.m. on Saturday. 
Police Officers will be compensated at the rate of one and one-half times the
hourly rate for all hours exceeding eighty (80) hours actually worked in a pay
period.  For purposes of this section, vacation leave, sick leave, comp time,
personal leave, holiday pay or any other time period that is not considered
hours actually worked will not be included in the minimum hours necessary to
qualify for overtime pay.
(Ord. 11-03.  Passed 1-31-11.)
   (b)   Non-FLSA exempt employees may elect to take compensatory time off in
lieu of receiving cash payment for overtime worked, at the rate of one and one-
half hours off for each hour of overtime worked.  Employees may accrue a
maximum of forty (40) hours of compensatory time at any one time.  All overtime
hours worked in excess of the forty (40) hour limit shall be paid in cash.
   (c)     The Employer may utilize "time off" or flexible hours in order to
avoid having employees work in excess of forty (40) hours in a work week or
eighty (80) hours in a pay period.  (Ord. 09-19.  Passed 12-14-09.)
   157.09  PHYSICAL EXAMINATIONS.
   Physicals for new employees required by the Village of Ottawa shall be paid
for by the Village. 
(Ord. 98-11.  Passed 5-11-98.)
   157.10  TRAVEL ALLOWANCES.
   Officials and employees shall be reimbursed for reasonable expenses incurred
on trips out of the Village on Village business when such expenses are approved
by Council prior to the trip. 
(Ord. 1089.  Passed 11-23-81.)
   157.11  EDUCATION EXPENSES.
   (a)   State required schooling for all regular policemen and firemen will be
paid for by the Village, when authorized by Council.
   (b)   State required schooling for Auxiliary Policemen will be paid one-half
by the Village and one-half by the Auxiliary.  The policeman is required to
work by the Village for one year after the completion of the schooling.  In the
event the policeman does not work for the Village for one year after the
completion of the schooling, he shall reimburse the Village and Auxiliary for
the cost of the schooling.
(Ord. 1089.  Passed 11-23-81.)
   157.12  IN-SERVICE TRAINING.
   Work-related training, necessary for the efficient and economical operation
of the Village, or required by local, State or Federal law, may be reimbursed
by the Village, providing that such training has been approved by the
department head, and the Mayor with the concurrence of Council.
(Ord. 1089.  Passed 11-23-81.)
   157.13  EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY.
   The Village is an equal opportunity employer and will provide employment
opportunities regardless of race, color, religion, sex, national origin,
handicap or ancestry.
(Ord. 1089.  Passed 11-23-81.)
   157.14  INDEMNIFICATION.
   (a)   The officials and employees of the Village shall be indemnified and
held harmless from any suit, claim, controversy, judgment, cost of suit, court
costs, bonds and liability resulting from the performance of their duties as
officials and employees of the Village.
   (b)   This section shall be applied retroactively, if necessary, to cover
acts done and performed in the past as well as those performed in the future by
the officials, boards, commissions and agencies together with the members
thereof and the employees of such boards, commissions and agencies and together
with the employees of the various departments of the Village.
   (c)   The indemnification provided by this section shall include, but not
necessarily be limited to the following officials, boards, commissions,
committees and agencies together with the members and employees thereof:
      (1)   All elected officials;
      (2)   All appointed officials;
      (3)   All employees and legal advisor;
      (4)   Utilities Board;
      (5)   Council Committees;
      (6)   Shade Tree Commission;
      (7)   Park Board;
      (8)   Planning Commission;
      (9)   Any duly designated Community Improvement Corporation for the
Village;
      (10)   Volunteer Fireman’s Dependent Board;
      (11)   Volunteer Fire Department;
      (12)   Police Department; and
      (13)   Income Tax Board.  (Ord. 1184.  Passed 4-13-87.)
   157.15  EDUCATIONAL OR ACHIEVEMENT BONUS. (REPEALED)
   EDITOR’S NOTE:  Former Section
157.15 was repealed by Ordinance 07-12.

review and all previous qualifications of licensures must be maintained. 
Relevant experience will be determined at time of hire.

   EDITOR’S NOTE: Pursuant to Resolution 2576, Council abolished the Mayor’s

171.  This chapter has been established for cross references and any future
legislation.
