   705.01  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall engage in or carry on the business of billposting, painting
or posting signs or posters for advertising purposes, distributing bills or
advertising matter of any kind, tacking cards or advertising within the Village
without first having obtained a license from the Mayor or his designee. (Ord.
283. Passed 12-3-23.)
   705.02  LICENSE FEES.
   Before issuance of the license required in Section
705.01 the Mayor or his designee shall receive a fee in the sum of fifty
dollars ($50.00) per year, or a fee of two dollars ($2.00) per day for license
for any period shorter than one year. Upon payment of such license fee, the
Mayor or his designee shall issue to such person a license as applied and paid
for.
(Ord. 283. Passed 12-3-23.)
   705.03  EXCEPTIONS.
   Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to authorize the Village to exact
and receive a license fee from merchants doing business in the Village for
advertising their own business. (Ord. 283. Passed 12-3-23.)
   705.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a minor
misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00).
Each day a violation continues or occurs shall constitute a separate offense.
CHAPTER 709
Amusement Devices
709.01   Definitions.
709.02   License required.
709.03   Application; fee.
709.04   Duration; nontransferable.
709.05   Gambling prohibited.
709.06   Inspections.
709.07   License revocation.
709.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      State licensing of portable amusement devices - see Ohio R.C. 1711.11
      Gambling - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
517
      Making or using slugs - see GEN. OFF.
545.11
      Tampering with coin machines - see GEN. OFF.
545.12
   709.01  DEFINITIONS.
   Unless the context clearly indicates otherwise, the meaning of the words
used in this chapter shall be as follows:
   (a)    "Coin or electrically operated amusement devices" means all amusement
devices displayed in a public or private place where the person or persons
operating the device are charged a valuable consideration for the use of the
device by the owner of the device or by the insertion of a coin or coins in the
device or any part thereof itself and where the operation of the device by
those so charged is designed to test the skill of the operators in achieving
the objective for which the device is designed. This definition includes coin
operated pool tables and juke boxes.
   (b)    "Display" means the keeping of a coin or electrically operated
amusement device anywhere within the Village, whether the device is located on
premises open to the general public or not.
   (c)    "Owner" means any person, firm or corporation who shall have in his
or its possession any coin or electrically operated amusement device.
      (Ord. 1107. Passed 12-20-82.)
   709.02  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, firm or corporation shall display any coin or electrically
operated amusement device without first obtaining a license from the Clerk-
Treasurer.
(Ord. 578. Passed 3-5-56.)
   709.03  APPLICATION; FEE.
   Each person, firm or corporation desiring to display a coin or electrically
operated amusement device shall make written application to the Clerk-Treasurer
for a license to display such devices. The application shall state the name and
address of the applicant; the name and address of the person, firm or
corporation who owns the device; the type of device or devices to be displayed;
the number of devices to be displayed; the address of the premises where the
device or devices will be displayed and such other matters as the Clerk-
Treasurer may consider pertinent. Upon receipt of the written application for
such license the Clerk-Treasurer shall issue a license for the display of a
coin or electrically operated amusement device after the payment by the
applicant of a license fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00).
(Ord. 578 Passed 3-5-56.)
   709.04  DURATION; NONTRANSFERABLE.
   (a)    The license issued under Section
 709.03 shall be for a period of not to exceed one calendar year and the
license shall expire December 31 in the year on which they are issued. When a
license is issued after January 1, but before December 31, in any year the
license fee shall not be prorated and the applicant shall be required to pay
the full fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00).
   (b)    The license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall not be
transferable from one person to another nor shall they be transferable from one
location to another.
(Ord. 578. Passed 3-5-56.)
   709.05  GAMBLING PROHIBITED.
   No person, firm or corporation licensed under the provisions of this chapter
shall permit betting or gambling in connection with the use or display of any
coin or electrically operated amusement devices.
(Ord. 1107. Passed 12-20-82.)
   709.06  INSPECTIONS.
   The Clerk-Treasurer shall order periodic inspections of the places where
coin or electrically operated amusement devices are displayed for the purpose
of determining that the devices are not being used in violation of any State
law or Village ordinance.
(Ord. 578. Passed 3-5-56.)
   709.07  LICENSE REVOCATION.
   In addition to the penalties hereinafter provided any person, firm or
corporation found guilty of violating Section
709.05 shall have their license revoked by the Clerk-Treasurer and the Clerk-
Treasurer shall not issue a license to display a coin or electrically operated
amusement device to a person, firm or corporation found guilty of violating
Section
709.05 for a period of one year from the date of the revocation. (Ord. 578.
Passed 3-5-56.)
   709.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter except for Section
709.05 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00). Whoever violates Section
709.05 shall be punished in accordance with Chapter
517 of the Codified Ordinances. Each day a violation continues or occurs shall
constitutes a separate offense.
CHAPTER 713
Community Antenna Television System
713.01   Short title.
713.02   Definitions.
713.03   Grant of nonexclusive franchise.
713.04   Effect of annexation.
713.05   Service standards and requirements.
713.06   Discriminatory practices prohibited.
713.07   Rates.
713.08   Rules and regulations.
713.09   Conditions for street occupancy.
713.10   Noncompetition with related services.
713.11   Liability and indemnification.
713.12   Franchise fee.
713.13   Approval of transfer.
713.14   Tampering with installation.
713.15   Forfeitures.
713.16   Performance bond.
713.17   Franchise term.
713.18   Manner of giving notices.
713.19   Separability.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Damage to equipment - see Ohio R.C. 4933.42, 4933.99
      Franchises - see PRELIM. UNIT TABLE A
   713.01  SHORT TITLE.
   This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the Community Television
Antenna Franchise Ordinance. (Ord. 851. Passed 9-28-70.)
   713.02  DEFINITIONS.
   For purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and their
derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the
context, the present tense includes the future, the plural includes the
singular, and the singular includes the plural. The word "shall" is always
mandatory and not merely directory.
   (a)    "Village" is the Village of Ottawa, Ohio.
   (b)    "Company" is Putnam TV Cable, Inc., the grantee of rights under this
franchise.
   (c)    "Council" is the Council of the Village of Ottawa, Ohio.
   (d)    "Person" is any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation
or organization of any kind.
      (Ord. 851. Passed 9-28-70.)
   713.03  GRANT OF NONEXCLUSIVE FRANCHISE.
   (a)    There is hereby granted by the Village to the Company the
nonexclusive right and privilege to erect structures and to construct, operate
and maintain upon, along, across, in, above and over the streets, alleys,
public ways and public places now laid out or dedicated and all extensions
thereof, and additions thereto within the Village, towers, poles, lines, wires,
cables and other television conductors and fixtures necessary for the
maintenance and operation in the Village of a community antenna television
system for the interception, receiving, amplifying, selling and distributing
television, electronic, electrical and radio signals, audio and video, to the
Village and its residents
   (b)    There is further granted by the Village to the Company the right and
privilege to attach or otherwise affix cable, wires and other necessary
apparatus to the pole facilities of any public utility company, even though the
same may cross the streets, sidewalks, public lands and highways of the
Village, provided that the Company or its successors or assigns secures the
permission or consent of the public utility companies concerned to affix such
cables or wires or other apparatus to their pole facilities.
   (c)    No resident of the Village shall be required to subscribe to the
service provided by the Company. (Ord. 851. Passed 9-28-70.)
   713.04  EFFECT OF ANNEXATION.
   Upon the annexation of any territory to the Village, the portion of any
utility that may be located or operated within such territory and upon the
streets, alleys or public grounds thereof, shall thereafter be subject to all
the terms of the franchise granted herein as though it were made an extension
thereof. (Ord. 851. Passed 9-28-70.)
   713.05  SERVICE STANDARDS AND REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)    The Company shall receive and distribute only television and radio
signals which are disseminated to the general public without charge by FCC
licensed broadcasting stations and other signals approved by the FCC, except
that the Company shall have the right to originate signals to its subscribers
for which no special charge shall be made.
   (b)    The Company shall carry approximately ten commercial television
channels, which shall include all of the major networks and one educational
channel if satisfactory reception is available, and the Company shall carry the
program of such channels in their entirety including announcements and
advertising and without picture degradation except as caused by forces beyond
the reasonable control of the Company and provided that this provision shall be
subject to any rules or regulations of the FCC amending or modifying the same.
   (c)    The Company shall construct, maintain and operate its system and
render efficient service in accordance with the rules and regulations as are,
or may be, set forth by Council.
   (d)    Whenever it is necessary to shut off or interrupt service for the
purpose of making repairs, adjustments or installations, the Company shall do
so at such time as will cause the least amount of inconvenience to its
customers, and unless such interruption is unforeseen and immediately
necessary, it shall give reasonable notice to its customers.
   (e)    The Company shall operate its system so that there will be a minimum
of or no interference with television or radio reception through individually
owner receiving antennas.
   (f)    The Company shall provide distribution facilities for the Village and
such public agencies as the Village may designate for audio services which can
communicate relevant information necessary to the civil defense of the Village
or the protection and relief of the Village from disaster, but the Company
shall not be required to provide the electronic equipment required for such
services.
   (g)    The Village shall have the right to supervise all construction and/or
installation work performed subject to the provisions of this chapter and to
make such inspection as it shall find necessary to insure compliance with
governing laws, rules and regulations.
   (h)    The Company shall during the existence of this franchise furnish
reasonable, adequate and efficient community antenna reception service to the
subscribers connected to its system within the Village as well as to
subscribers in suburban areas surrounding the Village where practicable, and
the Company agrees to maintain its system in reasonable repair and working
order; provided that these requirements may be temporarily suspended due to
disaster or emergency conditions or other circumstances beyond the reasonable
control of the Company. (Ord. 851. Passed 9-28-70.)
   713.06  DISCRIMINATORY PRACTICES PROHIBITED.
   The Company shall not, as to rates, charges, services, facilities, rules,
regulations or in any other respect, make or grant any preference or advantage
to any person, nor subject any person to any prejudice or disadvantage,
provided that nothing in this franchise shall be deemed to prohibit the
establishment of a graduated scale of charges and classified rate schedules to
which any customer coming within such classification would be entitled, and
provided further, that nothing in this franchise shall be construed so as to
prohibit the Company from rendering free service in such locations which the
Company, in its sole discretion, deems to be in the public interest.
(Ord. 851. Passed 9-28-70.)
   713.07  RATES.
   (a)   The charge by the Company to a residential subscriber for installing
his service connection for not more than three television receivers shall not
exceed fifteen dollars ($15.00) and the monthly service and maintenance charge
for a single receiver shall not exceed seven dollars and fifty cents ($7.50).
For each additional receiver, the monthly service charge shall not exceed one
dollar and fifty cents ($1.50). The charge by the Company for installing F.M.
service shall not exceed seven dollars and fifty cents ($7.50), and there shall
be no monthly service charge for the same; provided, however, F.M. service
shall be furnished only to subscribers of TV service. The charge by the Company
for installing movie channel service shall not exceed nineteen dollars and
ninety-five cents ($19.95) for each receiver and the monthly service and
maintenance charge for a single receiver shall not exceed eight dollars and
ninety-five cents ($8.95). The Company may charge a special rate of nine
dollars and ninety-five cents ($9.95) for installing movie channel service
during one month as an introductory offer. The Company shall not increase such
rates in any particular without the permission of Council. The Company shall
not increase or decrease its rates within the maximum limitations herein
imposed without first publishing notice of the increase or decrease of such
rates in a newspaper of general circulation in the Village at least thirty days
before the effective date of such rate increase or decrease. (Ord. 1096. Passed
3-22-82.)
   (b)    Prior to the commencement of any service hereunder, the Company shall
file in the office of the Clerk-Treasurer a schedule of all rates to be charged
by the Company for its services to be rendered under this franchise. Upon
making any change in the schedule of rates to be charged by the Company, the
Company shall file in the office of the Clerk-Treasurer the new rate schedule,
and such new rate schedule shall not be effective until the same is so filed.
   (c)    All rates and charges shall be made by the Company in accordance with
the prohibitions set forth in Section
713.06.
   (d)    The Company has the right to render free service in such locations
which the Company, in its sole discretion, deems to be in the public interest.
(Ord. 851. Passed 9-28-70.)
   713.08  RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Company shall have the authority to promulgate such rules, regulations,
terms and conditions governing the conduct of its business as shall be
reasonably necessary to enable the Company to exercise its rights and perform
its obligations, under this franchise, and to provide uninterrupted service to
all of its customers. Provided, however, that such rules, regulations, terms
and conditions shall not be in conflict with the provisions herein or the laws
of the State. (Ord. 851. Passed 9-28-70.)
   713.09  CONDITIONS FOR STREET OCCUPANCY.
   (a)    Use. All transmission and distribution structures, lines and
equipment erected by the Company within the Village shall be located so as to
cause minimum interference with the proper use of streets, alleys and other
public ways and places, and to cause minimum interference with the rights or
reasonable convenience of property owners who adjoin any of such streets,
alleys or other public ways and places.
   (b)   Restoration of Sidewalks. In case of any disturbances of pavement,
sidewalk, driveway or other surfacing, the Company shall, at its own cost and
expense and in a manner approved by Council, replace and restore all paving,
sidewalk, driveway or surface of any street or alley disturbed, in as good a
condition as existed before such work was commenced and shall maintain the
restoration in an approved condition for a period of one year.
   (c)    Relocation. In event that at any time during the period of this
franchise the Village shall lawfully elect to alter, or change the grade of,
any street, alley or other public way, the Company upon reasonable notice by
the Village shall remove, relay and relocate its poles, wires, cables and other
television fixtures at its own expense.
   (d)    Placement of Fixtures. Poles, posts and other structures of telephone
companies, power companies and others which may be made available to the
Company by such companies for leasing or licensing, shall be used to the extent
practicable in order to minimize interference with travel. Before the Company
sets poles or constructs any structure on Village property it shall file with
the Village notice of its intention, which notice shall specify the exact
location, height and dimensions of the poles or structures to be erected. The
poles or structures shall not be erected thereafter until such specifications
shall be approved in writing by the Council. In all street installations, the
wires, cables and other fixtures shall be not less than twenty feet from the
surface of the grounds.
   (e)    Temporary Removal of Wire for Building Removal. The Company shall on
the request of any person holding a building moving permit issued by the
Village, temporarily raise or lower its wires to permit the moving of
buildings. The expense of such temporary removal, raising or lowering of wires
shall be paid by the person requesting the same and the Village shall have the
authority to require such payment in advance. The Company shall be given not
less than forty-eight hours' advance notice to arrange for such temporary wire
changes.
   (f)    Tree Trimming. The Company shall have the authority to trim trees
upon and overhanging streets, alleys, sidewalks and public places of the
Village so as to prevent the branches of such trees from coming in contact with
the wires and cables of the Company with all trimming to be done under the
supervision and direction of the Village and at the expense of the Company.
   (g)    Removal of Wires, Poles and Installation From Premises of
Subscribers. The Company shall, on the request of any subscriber, promptly
remove all wires and installations from the premises of such subscriber.
   (h)    Removal of Wires, Poles and Installations from Village Streets. The
Company shall remove or cause to be removed from the streets of the Village and
from all public property all of the wires, poles and installations of any kind
or nature whatsoever which have been installed under the authority of this
franchise, upon the expiration of the terms of this franchise or any extension
thereof; the cessation of operation under this franchise by the Company, its
successors or assigns, for any reason whatsoever; or the forfeiture of this
franchise.
   (i)    Map of Service Area. The Company shall file with the Village at the
end of July of each year a map showing the area of the Village being served.
(Ord. 851. Passed 9-28-70.)
   713.10  NONCOMPETITION WITH RELATED SERVICES.
   (a)    The Company and its employees shall not engage in the sale, service,
rental or leasing of television receivers, radio receivers, or television or
radio receiver parts and accessories.
   (b)    The Company and its employees shall not require or attempt to direct
its subscribers to deal with any particular firm or person in regard to sale,
service, rental or leasing of television receivers, radio receivers or
television or radio receiver parts and accessories.
(Ord. 851. Passed 9-28-70.)
   713.11  LIABILITY AND INDEMNIFICATION.
   (a)    The Company shall, at all times, save the Village harmless from and
against any and all damages, lawful claims and demands for injury to person or
property which may be made against the Village in any manner growing out of the
maintenance and/or operation of the Community Antenna Television System or any
equipment of the Company. In case suit shall be filed against such Village,
either independently or jointly with such Company, to recover for any claim or
damages, the Company, upon notice to it by the Village, shall defend the
Village against such action. In the event of a final judgment being obtained
against the Village, either independently or jointly with the Company on
account of the acts of the Company, the Company will pay such judgment and all
costs and hold the Village harmless.
(Ord. 851. Passed 9-28-70.)
   (b)    The Company shall obtain and file with the Clerk-Treasurer and
continue to keep in full force and effect during the period of this grant,
liability insurance policies, or bonds of indemnity as the Company may elect,
conditioned for the benefit of persons suffering injury, loss or damage to
person or property, by virtue of the negligent operation of the Community
Antenna Television System by the Company. Such liability policies, indemnity
bonds, shall be in the sum of not less than five hundred thousand dollars
($500,000) for the death or injury to all persons affected, two hundred
thousand dollars ($200,000) for a single person and not less than two hundred
fifty thousand dollars ($250,000) for damage to property in any one accident.
(Ord. 851. Passed 9-28-70.)
   713.12  FRANCHISE FEE.
   The Company shall pay to the Village as an annual fee for the right and
privilege of this franchise a sum equal to three percent (3%) of the gross
received by the Company for cablevision service within the Village. The fee
shall be paid on the first anniversary date after operation is commenced and
annually thereafter.
   713.13  APPROVAL OF TRANSFER.
   Except for a mortgage or assignment to secure a loan or loans to construct
and/or operate the Community Antenna Television System, the Company shall not
sell or transfer the system and the privilege granted herein without first
securing the approval of Council for such sale or transfer.
(Ord. 851. Passed 9-28-70.)
   713.14  TAMPERING WITH INSTALLATION.
   (a)    Subscribers shall operate only one receiver at a time from each
outlet installed by the Company, and shall refrain from tampering with the
installation in any way. The Company shall have the right to discontinue
service to any subscriber tampering with its installation or related equipment
or attempting in any way to use the Company's service except as intended by the
Company. The subscriber violating these conditions shall not be entitled to any
rebate or other consideration by the Company.
   (b)    Subscribers to the Company's service shall not be required to assure
the Company that they will subscribe to the Company's service for any length of
time.
(Ord. 851. Passed 9-28-70.)
   713.15  FORFEITURE.
   (a)    If the Company fails to comply with any provision of this chapter, or
default in any of its obligations hereunder, except for causes beyond the
reasonable control of the Company, and fails within thirty days after written
notice from the Village to commence and, within a reasonable time, complete the
correction of such default, the Village shall have the right to revoke this
special privilege and all rights of the Company hereunder.
   (b)    In the event the Company shall be adjudicated bankrupt or placed in
receivership, the Village may declare the special privilege herein granted
forfeited and terminated.
   (c)    The Company shall not be deemed to be in default for performance of
any provision of this grant, nor shall any forfeiture be invoked for any
violation or failure to perform any provision hereof due to strikes, lockouts,
insurrections, acts of God, or any cause beyond the control of the Company.
(Ord. 851. Passed 9-28-70.)
   713.16  PERFORMANCE BOND.
   (a)    Annually, the Company will apply for and the with the Village a
performance bond in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000) conditioned upon
the Company's performance of its obligations hereunder.
(Ord. 851. Passed 9-28-70.)
   (b)    If the FCC, or any other government agency, should adopt rules and/or
regulations which will prevent the Company from complying with all of the
conditions of this chapter the bonds herein provided for shall not be
forfeited, and no penalty for nonperformance shall be imposed upon the Company.
(Ord. 853. Passed 11-2-70.)
   713.17  FRANCHISE TERM.
   The franchise and all rights granted herein shall take effect upon the
effective date of this chapter and shall continue in force and effect for a
period of twenty-five years.
(Ord. 851. Passed 9-28-70.)
   713.18  MANNER OF GIVING NOTICES.
   Whenever, by the terms of this chapter, notice is required to be given by
the Village to the Company, it may be given by leaving a paper writing thereof
during ordinary business hours at the office of the Company in the Village.
Whenever the Company is required to give notice to the Village, it shall do so
by leaving a paper writing thereof at the office of the Clerk-Treasurer during
ordinary business hours. (Ord. 851. Passed 9-28-70.)
   713.19  SEPARABILITY.
   Each section of this chapter and each part of each section is hereby
declared to be an independent section or part of a section and the holdings of
any section or part thereof to be unconstitutional, void, illegal, ineffective
or contrary to the provisions of law, for any reason, shall not affect any
other section or part of a section of this chapter.
(Ord. 851. Passed 9-28-70.)
CHAPTER 717
Dances and Dance Halls
717.01    Definitions.
717.02   Exceptions.
717.03   Dance permit; fee.
717.04   Application; form.
717.05   Dance hall license required; fee.
717.06   Investigation of applicant; inspection.
717.07   Issuance.
717.08   Duration.
717.09   Posting.
717.10   Forfeiture; issuance of new license.
717.11   Sanitary conditions; stairways.
717.12   Closing or vacating dance halls.
717.13   Right of entry.
717.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61
      Intoxicating liquor in dance hall - see Ohio R.C. 4933.14
   717.01  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    "Public dance" or "public ball" as used in this chapter, means any
dance or ball to which admission can be had by payment of a fee or by the
purchase, possession or presentation of a ticket, or token or in which a charge
is made for caring for clothing or other property, or any other dance to which
the public generally may gain admission, with or without the payment of a fee.
   (b)    "Public dance hall" means any room, place or space in which a public
dance or public ball shall be held. Any establishment open to the public, in
which food or beverages of any kind are provided, wherein dancing is permitted,
shall be a "public dance hall" and the same shall constitute a "public dance". 
(Ord. 811. Passed 7-1-68.)
   717.02  EXCEPTIONS.
   The provisions of this chapter shall in no way interfere with private
parties given in homes of people or with dances given by societies, clubs, or
corporations where the attendance is restricted to the members of such society,
club or corporation and their guests. Dances conducted with the approval and
under the jurisdiction of school boards are specifically exempted from the
provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 811. Passed 7-1-68.)
   717.03  DANCE PERMIT; FEE.
   No person, society, club or corporation shall hold a public dance or public
ball within the Village without having first obtained a permit therefor from
the Clerk-Treasurer, which shall be issued by him upon the payment of a fee of
twenty-five dollars ($25.00).
(Ord. 811. Passed 7-1-68.)
   717.04  APPLICATION; FORM.
   The person, society, club or corporation desiring a permit to hold a public
dance, shall make application to the Clerk-Treasurer in the following form:
APPLICATION
The Clerk-Treasurer:
   Sir:
      The undersigned, on behalf of __________________ hereby makes application
on _______________, 19 _, for a permit to give a public dance at No.
_____________ Street. It is hereby expressly agreed that such dance shall be
conducted in strict accord with the provisions of law regulating public dance
and public halls and the undersigned agrees that the permit is given and
accepted subject to the provisions of this application and that he shall be
held responsible for any violation of any provision of laws or ordinances
regulating such public dance. The owner or lessee of the premises in which such
dance is to be held, is _____________, No. ________________________ Street,
Name _____________________________ Occupation ___ ________________________
Address ____________________
(Ord. 812. Passed 7-15-68.)
   717.05  DANCE HALL LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE.
   No person shall hold any public dance or public ball in any hall within the
Village, until the dance hall in which the same is to be held first has been
licensed for such purpose, which license shall be issued by the Clerk-Treasurer
and the fee therefor shall be fifty dollars ($50.00), and all moneys received
by way of license fees shall be paid into the General Fund.
(Ord. 811. Passed 7-1-68.)
   717.06  INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT; INSPECTION.
   The Clerk-Treasurer shall examine all applications for dance hall licenses
and shall investigate each application to determine whether or not the dance
hall sought to be licensed complies with the applicable rules, regulations,
ordinances and laws. The Clerk-Treasurer shall make a reinspection of the
premises previous to granting the renewal license.
(Ord. 811. Passed 7-1-68.)
   717.07  ISSUANCE.
   No license for public dance hall shall be issued until it shall be found
that such hall complies with and conforms to all ordinances, health and fire
regulations of the Village and the State, is properly ventilated and supplied
with sufficient toilet facilities and is a safe and proper place for the
purpose for which it is to be used. (Ord. 811. Passed 7-1-68.)
   717.08  DURATION.
   Each license granted under Section
717.03 and
717.05 shall expire on the anniversary date of such license. (Ord. 812. Passed
7-15-68.)
   717.09  POSTING.
   Every public dance hall shall post its license in a conspicuous place within
the hall where the dance is held. (Ord. 811. Passed 7-1-68.)
   717.10  FORFEITURE; ISSUANCE OF NEW LICENSE.
   The license of any public dance hall may be forfeited or revoked by the
Clerk-Treasurer for disorderly or immoral conduct on the premises, or for the
violation of any of the rules, regulations, ordinances and laws governing the
or applying to public dance halls or public dances. If at any time the license
of a public dance shall be forfeited or revoked, at least six months shall
elapse before another license or permit shall be given for dancing on the same
premises.  (Ord. 811. Passed 7-1-68.)
   717.11  SANITARY CONDITIONS; STAIRWAYS.
   All public dance halls shall at all times be kept in a clean, healthful and
sanitary condition, and all stairways and other passages and all rooms
connected with a public dance hall shall be kept open and well lighted.
(Ord. 811. Passed 7-1-68.)
   717.12  CLOSING OR VACATING DANCE HALLS.
   The Clerk-Treasurer, the Chief of Police, or any other police officer shall
have the power and it shall be their duty to cause the place, hall or room,
where any dance or ball is held or given, to be vacated whenever any provisions
of this chapter with regard to public dances and public balls is being
violated, or whenever any indecent act shall be committed or when any disorder
of a gross, violent or vulgar character shall take place therein.
(Ord. 811. Passed 7-1-68.)
   717.13  RIGHT OF ENTRY.
   The Clerk-Treasurer, Chief of Police or any other member of the Police
Department shall be permitted to have access to all public dance halls, at all
times, and to investigate complaints made with respect thereto.
(Ord. 811. Passed 7-1-68.)
   717.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a minor
misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00).
Each day a violation continues or occurs shall constitute a separate offense.
CHAPTER 721
Peddlers and Solicitors
721.01   Definitions.
721.02   License required.
721.03   License application and requirements.
721.04   License fees and term.
721.05   Appeals.
721.06   Carrying and exhibiting license.
721.07   Business hours restricted.
721.08   License exceptions.
721.09   Employee peddlers to be licensed.
721.10   Revocation of license.
721.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61
      Home solicitation sales - see Ohio R.C. 1345.12 et seq.
      Charitable solicitations - see Ohio R.C. 2923.22
      Sales of goods and services within right of way of Interstate and other
State highways - see Ohio R.C. 5515.07
      Retail sales license - see Ohio R.C. 5739.17
   721.01  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    "Peddler" means any person who carries with him for the purpose of
sale at retail and immediate or future delivery, goods, wares, food or
merchandise, or any person who in person as principal or agent canvasses, sells
or otherwise obtains orders or commitments for sale, repair, or exchange of
goods, wares, food or merchandise or services.
   (b)    "Solicitor" means any person who obtains or seeks to obtain funds for
any cause whatsoever by means of canvassing from place to place.
   (c)    "Nuisance" means conduct by any peddler or solicitor which is likely
to irritate, mislead, endanger or harass a member or members of the public
within the Village of Ottawa, Ohio.
   The masculine gender as used herein shall include all genders.
(Ord. 1133. Passed 11-26-84.)
   721.02  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, salesman, firm or corporation shall engage in the business or
activity of peddler or solicitor in this Municipality without first obtaining a
license as provided in this chapter. (Ord. 1133. Passed 11-26-84.)
   721.03  LICENSE APPLICATION AND REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   Applications for licenses for peddlers or solicitors shall be filed
with the Village of Ottawa on a form provided, which may require, at least, the
following information:
      (1)       The name of the applicant and his physical description
including his birth date, height, weight, color of eyes and hair. The same
information shall be required of each employee, salesman, peddler or solicitor
of applicant operating in Ottawa during the license period. Each employee,
salesman, peddler or solicitor shall be treated as a separate applicant.
      (2)      The home address of the applicant and his social security
number.
      (3)       The name and address of the person by whom the applicant is
employed or for whom he is soliciting.
      (4)       The length of the applicant's service with such employer or
person for whom he is soliciting.
      (5)       All places of residence of the applicant and all employment
during the preceding year.
      (6)       The nature and character of the goods to be sold or services to
be furnished by the applicant or the purpose for which funds are being
solicited.
      (7)       The names of other municipalities in which the applicant has
recently conducted activities for which a license is herein required.
      (8)       That the applicant or his employer has complied with the
requirements of Ohio R.C. Chapter 1716 pertaining to charitable solicitations,
if applicable.
       (9)       Whether applicant has ever been convicted of any crime, and,
if so, the nature thereof and the penalty therefrom.
   (b)   Each applicant, employee, peddler or solicitor shall furnish a
description of any vehicle used in connection with his proposed activity in the
Village, the license plate number, date and number of his operator's license,
and where the vehicle will be located.
   (c)    Each adult applicant may be required to submit to fingerprinting for
identification and investigatory purposes.
   (d)      Each applicant shall furnish a recent photograph not more than one
year old or allow the Village to photograph him for an additional fee.  Such
application shall be made at least twenty-four hours before the license is
issued.
   (e)      If the Village of Ottawa determines after an investigation, that
the information furnished under the requirements of subsection (a) hereof is
correct, the applicant proposes to engage in lawful commercial or professional
enterprise and neither the applicant nor the enterprise upon which the
applicant proposes to engage constitutes a nuisance to the residents of the
Municipality, he shall issue a license to the applicant.
(Ord. 10-08.  Passed 5-24-10.)
   721.04  LICENSE FEES AND TERM.
   The license fee charged by the Village for the license required by this
chapter shall be set in the schedule of fees adopted by the Village of Ottawa. 
All annual licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall expire on
December 31 in the year when issued. Other licenses shall expire on the date
specified in the license. The annual rate for license fee shall be prorated by
the quarter year. (Ord.  10-08.  Passed 5-24-10.)
   721.05  APPEALS.
   Any applicant who has applied for a license in accordance with this chapter
and after an investigation was denied a license, may appeal to Council. Notice
of such appeal shall be filed with the Clerk within five days after the denial.
Such appeal shall be heard by Council at the next regular meeting and its
decision shall be final.
(Ord. 10-08.  Passed 5-24-10.)
   721.06  CARRYING AND EXHIBITING LICENSE.
   The license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be carried by
any salesman, peddler or solicitor at all times when peddling or soliciting and
shall be exhibited to any person being solicited and, on request, to any police
officer.
(Ord. 10-08.  Passed 5-24-10.)
   721.07  BUSINESS HOURS RESTRICTED.
   All business conducted by peddlers and solicitors governed under the rules
of this chapter shall be conducted between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m.
on Mondays through Saturdays with no business conducted on any Sunday or
holiday with the following exceptions:
   (a)   A peddler or solicitor requiring a Mobile Food License or a Temporary
Food License from the County in which they reside may operate on Sundays
through Saturdays between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. with the
exception of holidays.
   (b)   This section does not apply to invitees or national charitable
corporations licensed to do business in Ohio with recognized periods for
campaigns, provided the organizations have been licensed to solicit by the
Village of Ottawa.
      (Ord. 10-08.  Passed 5-24-10.)
   721.08  LICENSE EXCEPTIONS.
   No license shall be required of a salesman, peddler or solicitor for the
following:
   (a)       Soliciting only the purchase of or subscription for newspapers
having their principal sale or distribution in this Municipality or in the
County.
   (b)       Soliciting only for wholesale delivery to merchants, manufacturers
or other business or manufacturing establishments.
   (c)       Peddling or soliciting at the invitation or request of the person
contacted.
   (d)       Soliciting or peddling on behalf of and for any locally recognized
religious, educational, civic or charitable organization, without compensation
to the solicitor or peddler.
   (e)       Selling agricultural produce grown in Putnam County.
      (Ord. 10-08.  Passed 5-24-10.)
   721.09  EMPLOYEE PEDDLERS TO BE LICENSED.
   No person shall be hired by another to sell goods, wares, food, merchandise
or services in the Municipality as a peddler unless such person so hired has
been duly licensed as provided in this chapter.  (Ord. 10-08.  Passed 5-24-10.)
   721.10  REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   Any license issued under the provisions of this chapter may be revoked at
any time by the, Village of Ottawa if the licensee is guilty of fraud,
misrepresentation or any unlawful act in connection with his business or the
application required under Section
 721.03 or if the license violates any provision of this chapter. All fees paid
shall be forfeited in such event.
(Ord. 10-08.  Passed 5-24-10.)
   721.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
one hundred dollars ($100.00). Each day on which sales are conducted in
violation of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 10-08.  Passed 5-24-10.)
CHAPTER 725
Self-Service Dry Cleaning
725.01   Hours; exceptions.
725.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES

4107.46

   725.01  HOURS; EXCEPTIONS.
   Any establishment which offers self-service dry cleaning or laundering
equipment for public use shall not be open for business earlier than 6:00 a.m.
nor later than 11:00 p.m. unless there is an attendant on duty during these
hours; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to equipment
installed in a residential building offered for use only to residents of such
building. The attendant shall be an employee of the owner thereof and shall be
at least twenty-one years of age. (Ord. 781. Passed 4-3-67.)
   725.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor and shall be fined an amount not exceeding five hundred dollars
($500.00) plus costs of prosecution. Every day a violation continues or occurs
shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 781. Passed 4-3-67.)
CHAPTER 727
Video Service Provider Fee
727.01   Fee established.
   727.01 FEE ESTABLISHED.
   (a)   Council of the Village of Ottawa hereby establishes a VSP Fee that is
calculated by applying a VSP Fee percentage of three percent (3%) to the video
service provider’s gross revenues as defined in Section 1332.32(B) of the Video
Law.  All video service providers and cable television operators providing
video service in the Village shall apply the VSP Fee Percentage against gross
revenues as defined in the Video Law.
   (b)   The VSP Fee shall be paid by each video service provider providing
service in the Village on a quarterly basis but not sooner than forty-five (45)
days nor later than sixty (60) days after the end of each calendar quarter
(O.R.C. 1332.32(A)).
   (c)   The Mayor is authorized and directed to provide any video service
provider with notice of the VSP Fee Percentage as determined, which notice
shall be given by certified mail, upon receipt of notice from such video
service provider that it will begin providing video service in the Village
pursuant to a state-issued video service authorization.
(Ord. 08-09.  Passed 4-28-08.)

CODIFIED ORDINANCES OF OTTAWA
PART NINE - STREETS, UTILITIES AND PUBLIC SERVICES CODE
TITLE ONE - Street and Sidewalk Areas
            Chap.   
901.    Sidewalks.
            Chap.   
905.    Streets.
CHAPTER 901
Sidewalks
901.01   Supervision and specifications.
901.02   Repairs.
901.03   New construction.
901.04   Private construction; notice; assessment.
901.05   Special assessments.
901.06    Building or fence encroachment.
901.07   Materials on street or sidewalk.
901.99    Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Sidewalk maintenance - see Ohio R.C. 723.01, 723.011
   901.01  SUPERVISION AND SPECIFICATIONS.
   The Street Commissioner of the Village is hereby charged with the duty of
overseeing all sidewalks within the Village limits, which shall specifically
include inspection of existing sidewalks and reporting any necessary repairs to
Council, supervision of repairs or construction of new sidewalks and
establishing detailed specifications for sidewalks and the location of new
sidewalks. In establishing specifications for and location of specific
sidewalks, for purposes of repair or new construction, the Commissioner shall
attempt, insofar as possible, to establish uniformity throughout the Village,
seeking maximum utility with a minimum of damage to the property and trees,
shrubbery, fences, etc. already located thereon. Unless special circumstances
justify different specifications in constructing new sidewalks, the
specifications shall call for concrete sidewalks of a minimum width of four
feet and a minimum depth of four inches, upon sound footing. In locating
sidewalks, the Commissioner shall not be limited to Village property or street
rights of way, but may specify locations upon private property.
(Ord. 1121. Passed 3-5-84.)
   901.02  REPAIRS.
   The Street Commissioner shall report all necessary repairs of specific
sidewalks, together with his recommendation thereon, to Council. Council may
provide for the repair and restoration thereof or any portion thereof at the
expense of the Village, or may direct the owner of the abutting property to
repair the same, according to the detailed specifications of the Commissioner.
(Ord. 1121. Passed 3-5-84.)
   901.03  NEW CONSTRUCTION.
   Council may designate by specific resolutions, from time to time, specific
areas within the Village where new sidewalks shall be constructed, pursuant to
the detailed specifications of the Street Commissioner. The resolution may
provide that the cost shall be borne by the Village in which case the
resolution shall call for proper advertisement for bids as provided by law or
the resolution may provide that the cost thereof be assessed against the owners
of the property bounding or abutting such sidewalks.
(Ord. 1121. Passed 3-5-84.)
   901.04  PRIVATE CONSTRUCTION; NOTICE; ASSESSMENT.
   If Council elects to assess the cost of the repair or construction of
sidewalks, it shall adopt a resolution specifying the particular sidewalks to
be repaired or constructed. Appropriate written notice of the resolution shall
thereupon be served upon the owner or agent of each parcel of land abutting on
the sidewalks by the Chief of Police or a deputy, as provided in Ohio R.C.
729.02 and 729.03. If the owner of a parcel is a nonresident, notice of the
resolution shall be given by publication, as provided by Ohio R.C. 729.03. The
notice shall state, if the indicated repairs are not made within thirty days or
the indicated construction is not completed within sixty days, or within a
reasonable extension thereof expressly granted by the Street Commissioner, that
the Village shall perform or contract for such repair and construction on
behalf of the owner and shall report and assess the cost or materials furnished
by the Village, or both. However, the cost of sidewalks abutting publicly owned
property and the costs of crossover or intersection sidewalks shall be paid by
the Village and no part thereof so assessed. Council may provide for the
construction of sidewalks on only one side of a street or alley and it may
assess the cost thereof, equally or otherwise, upon the owners of the property
abutting on both sides of such street or alley. The assessed cost shall
constitute a lien on such property from the date the amount thereof is reported
to the owner and, if not paid to the Clerk-Treasurer within ten days
thereafter, the Clerk-Treasurer shall certify it, to the County Auditor, who
shall place it upon the tax duplicate and collect the same as provided by law.
(Ord. 1121. Passed 3-5-84.)
   901.05  SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS.
   Nothing herein contained shall be construed as preventing Council from
providing for the repair and/or construction of sidewalks, and recovering the
cost thereof by special assessments, as provided by Ohio R.C. 727.01 et seq.
(Ord. 1121. Passed 3-5-84.)
   901.06  BUILDING OR FENCE ENCROACHMENT.
   No person shall obstruct any street, alley, sidewalk or other public way by
erecting thereon any fence or building, or permitting any fence or building to
remain thereon. Each day that any such fence or building is permitted to remain
upon such public way shall be deemed a separate offense.
(Ord. 1121. Passed 3-5-84.)
   901.07  MATERIALS ON STREET OR SIDEWALK.
   No person shall encumber any street or sidewalk or, being the owner,
occupant or person having the care of any building or lot of land bordering on
any street or sidewalk, shall permit the same to be encumbered with barrels,
boxes, cans, articles, vegetation, obstructions or substances of any kind so as
to interfere with the free and unobstructed use thereof.
(Ord. 1121. Passed 3-5-84.)
   901.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00).
Each day a violation continues or occurs shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 1121. Passed 3-5-84.)
CHAPTER 905
Streets
905.01   Improvement conditions.
905.02   Opening permit.
905.03   Pavement restoration.
905.04   Barriers and warning lights.
905.05   Curbcuts.
905.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to establish and care for streets - see Ohio R.C. 715.19, 717.01,
723.01
   905.01  IMPROVEMENT CONDITIONS.
   No department of the Village shall accept, lay out, open, improve, grade,
pave, curb or light any street or other way, unless such street or way shall
have been accepted or opened or otherwise shall have received the legal status
of a public street or way prior to the effective date of this chapter; or
unless such street or way corresponds in location and extent with a street or
way shown on a recorded plat which shall have been legally accepted by Council.
(1968 Code 28.2)
   905.02  OPENING PERMIT.
   (a)    Required. No person, other than the Street Commissioner, Engineer, or
the authorized employee or agents of either, shall make any opening in any
street, alley, sidewalk, or public way of the Village unless a permit to make
such opening has been obtained prior to commencement of the work.  (1968 Code
28.4)
   (b)    Application and Deposit. Each permit for making such opening shall be
confined to a single project and shall be issued by the Street Commissioner or
his designee. Application shall be made on a form prescribed by Council, giving
the exact location of the proposed opening, the kind of paving, the area and
depth to be excavated and such other facts as may be provided for. The permit
shall be issued only after a cash deposit sufficient to cover the cost of
restoration has been posed with the Street Commissioner or his designee,
conditioned upon prompt and satisfactory refilling of excavations and
restoration of all surfaces disturbed.  (1968 Code 28.6)
   905.03  PAVEMENT RESTORATION.
   (a)    The opening and restoration of a pavement or other surface shall be
performed under the direction and to the satisfaction of the Street
Commissioner, and in accordance with rules, regulations and specifications
approved by Council.
   (b)    Upon failure or refusal of the permittee satisfactorily to fill the
excavation, restore the surface and remove all excess materials within the time
specified in the permit or where not specified therein, within a reasonable
time after commencement of the work, the Village may proceed without notice to
make such fill and restoration and the deposit referred to in the preceding
section shall be deemed forfeited. Thereupon such deposit shall be paid into
the Street Repair Fund except such part demanded and paid to the permittee as
the difference between the deposit and the charges of the Village for
restoration services performed by it. If the amount of such services performed
by the Village should exceed the amount of such deposit, the Clerk-Treasurer or
other proper administrative officer shall proceed to collect the remainder due
from such permittee. (1968 Code 28.8)
   905.04  BARRIERS AND WARNING LIGHTS.
   (a)    Barriers Around Excavations. Any person engaged in or employing
others in excavating, or opening any street, sidewalk, alley or other public
way, shall have such excavation or opening fully barricaded at all times to
prevent injury to persons or animals. (1968 Code 28.10)
   (b)    Warning Lights. Any person engaged in or employing others in
excavating or otherwise in any manner obstructing a portion or all of any
street, sidewalk, alley or other public way, at all times during the night
season shall install and maintain at least two illuminated red lamps which
shall be securely and conspicuously posted on, at or near each end of such
obstruction or excavation, and if the space involved shall exceed fifty feet in
extent, then at least one additional lamp for each added fifty feet or portion
thereof excavated or obstructed. (1968 Code 28.12)
   905.05  CURBCUTS.
   (a)    The Mayor, Municipal Director and Street Commissioner are hereby
authorized and directed to review all curbcut requests. Approval by two of the
three members of the curbcut committee is required for approval of any curbcut
in the Village. Council shall not be required to approve curbcuts.
   (b)    The approval of any curbcut shall be documented on a form to be
devised by the Municipal Director and shall be kept with the permanent records
of the Village.
(Ord. 1339. Passed 7-12-93.)
   905.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor. Each day on which a violation occurs or continues shall be deemed
a separate offense.
TITLE THREE - Utilities

CHAPTER 921
Water
921.01   Water usage rates.
921.02   Cross-connection, backflow prevention and water quality protection.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to provide and regulate water system - see Ohio R.C. 715.08,
717.01, 743.01
      Water pollution - see Ohio R.C. 715.08, 743.25
      Compulsory water connections - see Ohio R.C. 729.06, 743.23

      Fluoridation - see Ohio R.C. 6111.13
      Water pollution control - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 6111

   921.01  WATER USAGE RATES.
   (a)   There is hereby established pursuant to the recommendation of the
Utilities Board the following monthly rates to be charged for water usage in
the Village of Ottawa:
 
Beginning January 1, 2018
Water Connection and Debt Service Fee: $3.50 Per Service Connection
Per 100 cu. ft. or portion thereof     $5.23
Beginning January 1, 2019
Water Connection and Debt Service Fee: $3.50 Per Service Connection
Per 100 cu. ft. or portion thereof     $5.60
Beginning January 1, 2020
Water Connection and Debt Service Fee: $3.50 Per Service Connection
Per 100 cu. ft. or portion thereof     $5.99
Rates for industrial users located within the Village Corporation, with an
average daily use of 25,000 cubic feet or more, may be negotiated. 
(Ord. 17-13.  Passed 12-18-17.)
Rates for industrial users located within the Village Corporation, with an
average daily use of 25,000 cubic feet or more, may be negotiated. 
(Ord. 15-31.  Passed 12-21-15.)
   (b)   A penalty of ten percent (10%) of the outstanding balance shall be
added to each bill for failure to pay for water charges by the due date. 
Payments must be postmarked or received by the due date.  The water charges
levied shall be billed monthly.
(Ord. 15-25.  Passed 12-21-15.)
   (c)   The owner(s) of all lots, lands and premises hereinafter developed
located within the Village of Ottawa and that are hereafter annexed by the
Village of Ottawa, shall connect with the Village of Ottawa water distribution
system upon such water distribution system being made reasonably available to
such owners.
(Ord. 04-22.  Passed 10-11-04.)
   (d)   There is hereby established a rate for residents of the Village who
have Village water available, but are not connected to the system.  Said rate
is established based on the perceived benefits derived from the Village water
system.  Said rate shall be three dollars and fifty cents ($3.50) per month to
be billed monthly along with other water bills.
   (e)   The funds received from the collection of the rates and charges
hereinafter provided shall be deposited as received with the Clerk-Treasurer,
who shall keep the same in a separate fund designated “Water Fund”.  Subject to
the provisions of any ordinance or indenture of mortgage authorizing the
issuance of and securing mortgage revenue bonds for said System, monies in said
Fund shall be used for operation, maintenance, repair an management of the
System, fund for payment of debt charges on bonds issued for extensions and
improvements of the System, and any surplus in said Fund over and above the
requirements hereinbefore mentioned may be used for enlargements of and
replacements to the System and parts thereof. 
(Ord.  02-35.  Passed 12-16-02.)
   (f)   Each water charge levied pursuant to this section is hereby made a
lien upon the premises charged therewith, and if the same is not paid, it shall
be certified to the Auditor of Putnam County, who shall place the same on the
tax duplicate, with the interest and penalties allowed by law, and be collected
as other Municipal taxes are collected.
(Ord. 01-14.  Passed 7-23-01.)
   (g)   The Utilities Board shall make and enforce such rules and regulations
as it may deem necessary for the enforcement of the provisions hereof, for the
proper determination and collection of the rates and charges herein provided,
and for the safe, efficient and economical management of the Water Treatment
System; and such rules and regulations, when not repugnant to existing
ordinances of the Village or laws of the State of Ohio, shall have the same
force and effect as ordinances of Council.
   (h)   No lot, parcel of land, building or premises now or hereafter used by
the Village for municipal purposes shall be subject to water charges hereby
established.
   (i)   Nothing in this section shall be construed as prohibiting the Village
from entering into contracts for providing water services outside the Village
corporate limits at different rates other than contained in subsection (a)
hereof and upon such terms and conditions as it deems necessary.
(Ord. 94-19.  Passed 12-19-94.)
   (j)   (1)   No person shall purchase bulk water in the Village of Ottawa
without first making an application therefore at the Clerk’s Office.  Bulk
water is water that is purchased from the device located east of the Village of
Ottawa Municipal Garage.  Upon review of the application, the Utilities
Director or Municipal Director or their designee retains the right to deny the
privilege of selling bulk water to any person at any time.
      (2)   A service fee of four dollars and fifty cents ($4.50) will be
assessed with every purchase of bulk water.  The general rate shall be as
follows:
Beginning January 1, 2016
         1,000 gallons water or portion thereof - $12.53
         100 cubic feet water or portion thereof - $9.37
Beginning January 1, 2017
         1,000 gallons water or potion thereof - $13.40
         100 cubic feet water or portion thereof - $10.02
For purposes of the service fee, any agreement to purchase bulk water for a
period of time not exceeding seven days shall be considered a purchase of bulk
water.  (Ord. 16-02.  Passed 1-11-16.)
      (3)   The applicant/user must give the Village notice of at least twenty-
four hours before purchasing unless the Utilities Director or Municipal
Director agrees to notice of less than twenty-four hours because of an unusual
circumstance.
      (4)   The applicant/user may only purchase bulk water weekdays during
staffed hours unless special arrangements are made in which case the applicant/
user will be responsible for paying the time costs for the Village employees
required to accommodate applicant/user’s special arrangements.
      (5)   The Village does not assume any liability for the quality of bulk
water after delivery to applicant/user.
      (6)   The applicant/user will be liable to the Village for any extra
costs, fines or penalties incurred by the Village as a result of any deviations
of this subsection.  Violation of this subsection would result in permanent
suspension of purchasing privileges.  The Utilities Director or Municipal
Director shall enforce the provisions of this subsection.
         (Ord.  01-13.  Passed 7-23-01.)
   921.02  CROSS-CONNECTION, BACKFLOW PREVENTION AND WATER QUALITY PROTECTION.
   (a)     All new and existing water service connections, which in the opinion
of the Village endangers or can endanger the public water supply from an
existing or anticipated cross-connection shall install an approved backflow
prevention device (BPD).
   (b)     The water user shall at his or her cost on written notice by the
Municipal Director, or his designee, install a BPD approved by the Municipal
Director, or his designee, of a type which meets the regulations of the
Environmental Protection Agency, the Sanitary Code, and the American Water
Works Association.
       (1)     If the water user fails to install an approved BPD within thirty
days from receipt of written notice, or such date agreed by the parties, this
Village shall:
         A.     Discontinue water service until the BPD is installed, or
         B.     Install the device and charge the cost thereof to the user
water sewer bill.
   (c)   All BPD's shall be inspected annually on or before the anniversary
date of the installation of the device and shall report the results in writing
to the Village.
   (d)     Failure to perform the annual inspection and an inspection sheet in
accordance with subsection (c) or within thirty days thereof, hereof shall
result in a penalty of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) being added to the water
sewer bill of the delinquent user for each month, or portion thereof, of
noncompliance.
      (1)     If after one year and one month, noncompliance continues, the
water user shall be notified by certified mail of the noncompliance.  If
compliance with written notice to the Village is not obtained within thirty
days from the notice, water service shall be discontinued without further
notice by the Village.  Renewal of service shall be allowed only after written
notice to the Village of a proper inspection and the assessment of a fifty
dollar ($50.00) renewal of service fee, which shall be added to the user's
water sewer bill.
   (e)     Inspectors must provide proof of proper licensing to the Village.
Such licensing may be obtained from the Ohio Department of Commerce, the
Operating Training Committee of Ohio or the equivalent approved by Municipal
Director or his designee.
   (f)     The water user shall permit a qualified Village representative to
investigate and survey backflow prevention and possible cross-connections as
part of a control program for the Village and is required by the Environmental
Protection Agency. Advanced notice by the Municipal Director, or his designee
will be given prior to inspection. This inspection is separate from yearly
maintenance inspection and is an investigative survey only and is at no
additional cost to water user.
   (g)     Any charges incurred per
921.02(b)(1)(b), penalty set forth in
921.02 and the charge set forth in
921.02(d)(1) shall be deemed to be a "water charge" as set forth in
921.01(f) and shall become a lien upon the premises being served in the same
manner as set forth in such section.   
(Ord. 18-12.  Passed 7-9-18.)
CHAPTER 925
Sewers
925.01   Definitions.
